1093758055425044480.text: Hopefully this provides some clarity! Of course, tweet back with questions. Special thanks to @ameensol for pointing out that some expectation-setting is required.

1093758054200299520.text: At a minimum, I think we should expect short-lived , single-client , public  testnets. I also suspect we're going to see some short-lived , multi-client , public  testnets. What I don't expect to see is a long-lived , multi-client , public  testnet. 9/n

1093758053013323776.text: Luckily, we don't need to sit on our hands until we have it on a platter from the EF. In the meantime, we can be working on short-lived single and multi-client testnets. These are great stepping stones towards the testnet and major achievements on their own.  8/n

1093758051834707968.text: The EF are designing the specification and they will most likely produce the test vectors, so ultimately, we're waiting on research to mature. That being said, it's our job as implementers to help them and we'll be doing so!  7/n

1093758050626809857.text:
To get to the  testnet, we need:

- A specification version that we all agree is fit for purpose.
- Test-vectors so implementations can determine if their implementation is correct before attempting to debug a live system.  6/n

1093758049519423490.text: So ideally we want to see a long-lived, multi-client, public testnet. That's the holy grail . However, what do we need to get there? 5/n

1093758048252776448.text: Testnets can be short-lived  or long-lived . Short-lived testnets give no guarantee that the blockchain will still exist next week, whilst long-lived testnets are harder to maintain. A long-lived testnet more accurately reflects the real-world demands of Ethereum. 4/n

1093758047120281600.text: Testnets can also be public  or private . Private testnets are handy for developers but they're not realistic. Ethereum is a public blockchain and therefore needs to withstand all the harshness of the public internet. 3/n

1093758045975236610.text: Testnets can be single-client  or multi-client . Single-client testnets are a great achievement, but they don't test interoperability. Eth 2.0 seeks client diversity and interoperability is a must. 2/n

1093758044725342209.text:
The phrase "Q1 2019 Beacon Chain Testnet" has been thrown around lately.

A testnet can have multiple different qualities and we seek to explore what to expect in Q1. 1/nhttps://twitter.com/sigp_io/status/1093750944590778368 …

1090134949615652865.text:
Exciting news for #lighthouse!

Gossipsub allows efficiently segregating the p2p network into topics. Each shard will have its own topic, avoiding a noisy global broadcast domain.https://twitter.com/sigp_io/status/1090133542728654848 …

1084735363745103874.text: I hope this was helpful and you have more of an understanding of the BN/VC relationship. Please let me know if you have any questions, comments or disagreements! 10/10

1084735362402942977.text: As we build out the VC, the BN API will crystallize. Once we're across the requirements, we'll start liaising with other Eth 2.0 teams to ensure we all agree upon a common API. Personally, I'd love to see BN/VC interoperability across implementations. 9/10

1084735360762970112.text: Our VC is taking shape in lighthouse PR#154 (https://bit.ly/2CorpFg ). Now, it's rough and focused on ensuring the gRPC APIs are solid. Later, we'll be focusing on security. Goals: security review from @trailofbits and formal verification from @rv_inc. 8/10

1084735358837747712.text: Slash protection involves ensuring that a validator never signs two messages that are conflicting (equivocating, in CBC-speak). If a VC is fastidious about managing it's history, it's impossible for a malicious BN to cause it to produce "slashable" messages. 7/10

1084735357587869696.text:
Apart from keeping a schedule, there are two other important roles filled by the VC:

- Key management
- Slash protection

For key management, an ideal VC will delegate signing to a hardware security module (HSM) (@LedgerHQ, etc). 6/10

1084735356216389632.text: The VC also keeps track of the time. Whenever it is time for a validator to act (e.g., produce a block, attest to a shard, etc) the VC requests some data from the BN, signs/completes that data and sends it back. 5/10

1084735354836377600.text: The VC is a specialized, thin program run by Eth 2.0 validators. It connects to the BN via gRPC and reads the "shuffling", the delegation of duties among validators. 4/10

1084735353477566469.text: A "validator client" (VC) is a separate program to the "beacon node" (BN). The BN connects to the p2p network and performs the heavy lifting in syncing the chain and choosing the canonical head. It's much like Parity or Geth. 3/10

1084735352080723968.text: We're using #gRPC for comms between the "validator client" and the "beacon node" binaries (programs). Community feedback suggests people are keen for gRPC. It's a great framework from Google, if you're not familiar with it, check it out. 2/10

1084735350537211909.text:
Sorry Twitter , I've been quiet about #Lighthouse recently. Updates:

- Notes + video from lighthouse call #0: https://bit.ly/2squTlN 
- Text update (notes are better, IMO): https://bit.ly/2Fvs5LX 

Most interestingly, we've started the validator client. Yay!  More... 1/10

1075243557127041024.text: So, @VitalikButerin just contributed 1,000 ETH to #lighthouse development. We're very appreciative for this and will turn it into dev power!  We're going to progressively liquidate it into $$ as it is relatively stable compared to labor. Look forward to more Eth 2.0 progress!https://twitter.com/VitalikButerin/status/1075210851278295040 …

1074897674929823744.text: We're going to start processing applications in the next couple of days, so now's a good time to apply if you've been considering it! https://twitter.com/paulhauner/status/1072023255882452992 …

1072023269060993026.text: That's all from me. I'll gauge how this new update format goes. If we get more input that from the blog posts, I'll stick with it and save the blog for large volume posts (and possible archiving these tweet storms)  Hit us up with any feedback! 12/12

1072023267647545344.text: .@jcksie has raised discussion about swapping the endianness used in the spec. @ethstatus are targeting low-resource devices which is a challenging and necessary endeavor. Swapping from big to little gets us closer to the hardware. Get involved: https://bit.ly/2RHvFG6  11/12

1072023266280169472.text: .@drakefjustin has reached out to the community for input regarding the economics of interest rates for validators. I think this is a great initiative and would love to see more discussion here. Get involved: https://bit.ly/2L5l0m5  10/12

1072023265017647104.text: ETH 2.0 clients seem keen to replace the present JSON RPC with a gRPC alternative. I support this, but I'd love to hear some thoughts from existing client devs. I haven't heard any strong negative arguments yet, I'd love to hear some for the sake of a balanced discussion.  9/12

1072023263633563648.text: The recent changes in the ETH 2.0 spec have made us reconsider how we go about building the client. We're planning to switch to some of the more static components (e.g., libp2p, RPC interfaces, helper functions, etc) until there's a release candidate of the spec. 8/12

1072023262459088896.text: The ETH 2.0 spec has changed significantly in the past weeks which has antiquated some of our more complex functions (block validation, etc) which is painful. However, I support the updates so it's a long-term gain  Hopefully all involved can learn from this. 7/12

1072023261158883329.text:
I see two themes for funding open-source:

1. A commercial offering "around" the product. E.g.  consultancy, "wrapper" products.
2. Donations from profitable stakeholders. E.g. grants, in-protocol DAOs.

Both need profitable companies and (1) keeps profits closer to devs. 6/12

1072023259892174851.text: At the last @SydEthereum meetup , I presented about #Lighthouse and the challenges for businesses producing open-source public goods. Their support was overwhelming and I'm keen to be more open about the challenges. 5/12

1072023258529026048.text: We're excited to see some Rust-newbies contributing to the code base. To me this means that we've created an an approachable project and we're helping  contributors learn as they help us. I hope this is the case!  4/12

1072023257283358722.text: #Lighthouse is seeing some repeat contributors from the community, which is really exciting. Our SSZ Tree Hash implementation is underway by mjkeating and g-r-a-n-t has been adding tests. These contributions are hugely appreciated, thank you  3/12

1072023255882452992.text: #SigmaPrime is still in the process of hiring a new Rust developer . We've had some great applicants but we'd love to see some more. If you want to build and contribute to the security of Ethereum, you should apply: https://bit.ly/2QmGLnl  2/12

It would be great to see hardware wallets designed for Ethereum PoS validation that keep internal state to protect validators from slashing.

If a device keeps a consistent history of previously signed attestations it can protect a validator from creating slashable messages.

1048457088253317120.text: In case you were wondering, producing fortnightly updates was 100% our original idea and not stolen from @prylabs. Theirs are bi-weekly. Big difference.

1048052979465510912.text:
We just published an update on our Eth 2.0 progress! Achievements this fortnight:

- BLS aggregate signature verification
- Block pre-processing & benchmarks
- SimpleSerialize implementation and draft spec

https://lighthouse.sigmaprime.io/update-01.html 
@ethZed @AgeManning @_chrisnatoli

1047042204819173377.text:
If you were in the Eth 2.0 call, you might have heard that Lighthouse has been doing block processing benchmarks!

On my consumer laptop (X1 carbon, i5) and w/ 10% of ETH supply staking we can validate a block and its BLS signatures in 0.066 seconds.https://github.com/ethereum/beacon_chain/issues/103#issuecomment-425100871 …

1045280682082062339.text: If you’re having trouble viewing it on your phone, switch Github to desktop mode

1045279151744118785.text:
Sigma Prime has two core offerings; our Eth 2.0 client and infosec services. On our core team we have experienced security professionals targeting smart contract security. 

Here’s an example of what you can expect when you engage us: https://github.com/sigp/havven-audit/tree/master/2018-06-06_b5a6cdb … (It’s the PDF)

1042996127820181504.text: I'm sharing because I've never met someone else who uses it and I found it by accident. I think it's a great tool, well done to the contributors.

1041607706392506374.text: Just to be clear, this is a work in progress!

1041597854731493376.text: We're excited to announce a brand-new Ethereum 2.0 implementation in Rust! We've been working on this publicly for a couple of months now but we're making it official with a blog post. Watch this space, we'll keep you posted with regular updates. @sigp_iohttps://lighthouse.sigmaprime.io/update-00.html

1038148113146556416.text: Good luck to the @ETHBerlin hackers! It was a pleasure to volunteer on the registration desk.

1033250889610350592.text: How the Ethereum 2.0 shuffling algorithm works. It's a deterministic, pseudo-random shuffle designed to ensure validators are distributed evenly across blocks and shards.https://notes.ethereum.org/s/HJJwWYCUX

1031488568340824064.text: Looking forward to it! (We’re actually @sigp_io, but that’s cool!)https://twitter.com/SydEthereum/status/1031397539205894144 …

1025042239251050496.text: When life gives you O(c), make shardonnay.

1021352291889102848.text: Then suffer because the Python impl. didn't reject these solutions and the 21 bit limit wasn't obvious until you were several days deep into an OpenGL impl.

1021351883225554944.text: Theoretical (viz., not possible) optimisations on Equihash. Expand your list size and get more post-difficulty-filter solutions, faster. Then have those solutions rejected because they're more than 21 bits.https://twitter.com/AgeManning/status/1021341103805513729 …

1019137430845157376.text:
Our Rust implementation of the Ethereum Beacon Chain spec is now 99% on-par with the reference impl. We're missing a few BLS features and a couple of integration tests.

It's called "Lighthouse" -- another form of rusty beacon. You can find it here:https://github.com/sigp/lighthouse

1013384223514873856.text: More info: I am looking for a permanent donation I can keep using each year. I’ll use it to help people find resources, print & scan documents, access the internet & write resumes. Check out http://sydneyhomelessconnect.com

1013376129091145730.text: I run the tech desk at Sydney Homeless Connect — an annual event @ Syd Town Hall collating services for ppl exp. homelessness. We help people with their tech. I’m looking for 2-3 modern laptops (not fancy) to assist my ops. If you’re in Syd w/ spare laptops, please DM/reply

989345037828829184.text: The "funding crunch" is the new "difficulty bomb": when the ETH hybrid PoS/PoW contract exhausts its initial 1M ETH allocation through interest payments (rewards) to validators.https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/master/EIPS/eip-1011.md#issuance …

988179968935903232.text: Speed variation: reboot if CPU utilisation drops below 50%.

988179800182280192.text: The uptime challenge: 100 ETH locked in a smart contract for 100 days, private key in your /tmp dir.

987694535248523264.text: Faster Casper binary consensus sims; validators now use a shared database and only share hashes. Less recursion, moar optimise. Blockchain consensus next, then graphical sims. Keen to meet D3.js gurus. https://github.com/sigp/cbc-casper-js …

978075285219258369.text: We've started a JS simulator of @VladZamfir's Capser TFG. Inspired by the Python "cbc-casper" implementation, the goal is to get some in-browser graphical sims. It's cmd-line for now, but watch this space! https://github.com/sigp/cbc-casper-js …
